sense.name: hesitate in confusion, doubt or fear
sense.examples: We start and boggle at every unusual appearance. He boggled much at the freeing his son from his debts. The world boggles at Rhianna's goggles. She boggled at paying such a price. We stopped what we were doing and boggled at each other and the streaming windows.

sense.name: overcome with amazement; flabbergast
sense.commentary: Syntax includes: NP1[agent|stimulus] BOGGLE NP2[experiencer] Often occurs adjectivally.
sense.examples: This boggles the mind! In Tokyo, she boggled fashion minds by turning out in a futuristic metallic spotted pantsuit. Scientists have been boggled as the number of sick pelicans along the coast of California increases. Scientists Boggled by Enormous Octopus. Initially pleased, I soon was boggled by the instability i found there.

sense.name: make a bungle or botch of
sense.commentary: Syntax includes: NP1[agent] BOGGLE NP2[theme] Occurs often adjectivally.
sense.examples: His affairs were found to be woefully boggled. He boggled the whole thing. Bill set up for a horse doctor, but he boggled everything, an' killed more'n he cured. While she boggled the start with a miscue, she quickly regained her composure.
